image.altText: Large explosion of orange lights up the skyline in gaza at night

items.synopsis: Israeli air and ground forces are stepping up operations in the Gaza Strip, Israel's chief military spokesperson says, amid reports of heavy bombing of the besieged enclave.

title.children: Israel says ground forces 'expanding activities' in Gaza, as UN calls for truce

image.altText: A mum with her hair in a pony tail talks to her young son who has blonde hair

items.synopsis: Doctors and friends dismissed Jessica's concerns when her son stopped talking. When he was eventually diagnosed with autism, she wished she hadn't agreed to take a "wait and see" approach.

title.children: 'Don't wait and see': Jessica wishes she sought a second opinion when her son fell silent at 16 months old

image.altText: A man carrying a plastic shopping bag walks across rubble and destroyed buildings

items.synopsis: There is a disturbing lack of bipartisanship on the question of the Middle East, which has real world consequences and seems to potentially point to an ugly new direction in domestic politics, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Comments from Australian leaders about the Middle East set an ominous tone for our political future

image.altText: A young woman holding flowers after graduating next to flowers and a tribute

items.synopsis: When 21-year-old Lilie James failed to return home from work on Wednesday, a welfare phone call led police to a tragic crime scene they found confronting.

title.children: Shock waves after suspected murder of 21-year-old Lilie James spotlights violence against women

image.altText: Sharon Graham, Peter Koenig, Gregory Roser and Bruce Saunders.

items.synopsis: Sharon Graham has been found guilty of masterminding the so-called 'woodchipper murder' of the mild-mannered Bruce Saunders — a cash-poor but asset-rich man deemed to be worth more dead than alive.

title.children: The sinister web of sex and deception that led to a gruesome murder

image.altText: A close up of Yahya Sinwa at a rally among a crowd of people.

items.synopsis: Twelve years ago, Yahya Sinwar was inside an Israeli jail cell with no means of escape. Now, Israel has accused the Hamas Gaza chief of playing a role in planning the October 7 attack, with officials calling him a "dead man walking".

title.children: This chief of Hamas in Gaza was once a prisoner of Israel. Now Yahya Sinwar is a 'dead man walking'

image.altText: A collage of buildings on Nauru, an eye with a tear, a woman holding a child and an unidentifiable security guard

items.synopsis: 'Simone' was the worker behind 'The Nauru Files' — the largest leak inside Australia's system of offshore detention. She's never spoken out to reveal why she did what she did — until now.

title.children: 'Simone' had a choice — quit her job, or leak files about the reality of life for children and families on Nauru

image.altText: Pills

items.synopsis:
Don't get it twisted, drug decriminalisation does not mean hard drugs are legal. Here's what you need to know about the ACT's new laws.

The change means people found with small amounts of illicit drugs will get a fine rather than a criminal penalty.

title.children: Canberra's nation-leading drug-decriminalisation laws begin today. So, what changes?

image.altText: Sales standing in a dining room, smiling at camera.

items.synopsis: Recently, I've been one of the many Australians who are avoiding the news. What is going on, when the news is losing not just its regular audience, but alienating a career newshound like me, asks Leigh Sales.

title.children: Journalists must ask themselves the tough questions about why people are avoiding the news

image.altText: an aerial of a burned out home

items.synopsis: Damian Fairbairn's home is between Tara and Chinchilla in the Western Downs. He said emergency alerts has been inconsistent where he lives.

title.children: Queensland authorities investigating after reports some residents near bushfires didn't get alert to leave

image.altText: A boat speeds along the water under a blue sky towards the Horizontal Falls in the Kimberley, leaving behind a wake pattern.

items.synopsis: A local Aboriginal corporation says it's working towards phasing out boats passing through the gaps at the Kimberley region's Horizontal Falls, which attract swarms of visitors every year.

title.children: Traditional owners move to ban boats passing through gaps in falls at WA tourist mecca

image.altText: A dated image of a happy smiling woman.

items.synopsis: A 77-year-old man who cannot be identified for legal reasons is charged by police in Western Australia with the murder of Sharon Fulton, who vanished in 1986 and whose body has never been found.

title.children: Elderly man faces court 37 years after allegedly murdering Perth mother Sharon Fulton

image.altText: A lobster being held about to be measured

items.synopsis: Air gun testing critical to Western Australia's offshore oil, gas and energy ambitions is "dazing" the state's valuable western rock lobsters, a new study finds.

title.children: Lobsters left 'concussed' and potentially dead after seismic testing vital to offshore energy industries

image.altText: An aerial view of a factory surrounded by green trees and red dirt.

items.synopsis: Businesses across northern Australia are chasing a Kimberley beef company for significant unpaid debts, according to industry sources.

title.children: Family-run businesses allegedly owed millions by company behind only abattoir in northern WA

image.altText: A man sitting in front of a computer, wearing a colourful T-shirt and a red head-band.

items.synopsis: The movie Dumb Money tells how a group of amateur investors made a killing with GameStop stocks, and almost bankrupted huge investment firms in the process. Here's the true story that inspired it.

title.children: Redditors made billions on the US stock market during the pandemic. Now they've made a movie about it

image.altText: Three female soldiers stand near a truck smiling. They wear dark green and brown army fatigues.

items.synopsis: For centuries, women have been part of battlefields, including on the frontline. So why do we seem to have so much trouble acknowledging and commemorating them?

title.children: Women have fought on the frontline for centuries. So why aren't they acknowledged?

image.altText: A black and white photo of a non-Indigenous man walking through a swamp with his bike near an Indigenous man with a spear.

items.synopsis: After riding 3,000 kilometres from Adelaide to Darwin in 1914, Ted Ryko was lauded as a hero. Then World War I broke out and facing harassment, he fled to Arnhem Land, where he would form a unique connection with Aboriginal people.

title.children: Accused of being a spy, world-record-breaking adventurer Ted Ryko found refuge in outback Aboriginal communities

image.altText: Madonna's Rebel Heart tour

items.synopsis: After all Madonna's decades of swallowing and spitting out every other cultural taboo for a woman in music, the age barrier is her last hill to climb. And she's doing it in a crotchless corset and heels, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: Madonna takes on the last real taboo for women — ageing

image.altText: A huge felled tree trunk is transported on the back of a truck through a central Hobart street at night time.

items.synopsis: The latest photo of a large tree on the back of a Victorian truck driven through the centre of Hobart dismays opponents to Tasmania's native forest logging practices, who describe it as "outrageous" — but it's completely legal.

title.children: This tree, hundreds of years old, was trucked through central Hobart. It was legal to log

image.altText: A doctor using a stethoscope on a patient.

items.synopsis: Urgent care clinics have been opened around Australia to help ease the pressure on hospital emergency departments — so where are they? When are they open? And do they bulk-bill?

title.children: Urgent care clinics — what are they, where are they, and when should you use them?

image.altText: A Japanese Australian woman dressed in eclectic clothing and large sunglasses performs onstage.

items.synopsis: Disappearing Cantonese dialects and centuries-old Vietnamese instruments feature alongside bilingual K-rap and punk Malaysian street art in a program that champions freedom of expression.

title.children: 'There's nothing like it': Why OzAsia is the major cultural festival you should know about

image.altText: Fijian Tongan woman stands holding a shell wearing latex gloves with historic pacific clothes hung behind her

items.synopsis: The gallery houses artefacts of deep cultural significance to the diaspora in Australia, including a rare 1,000-year-old replica Rotuman headdress.

title.children: Dive into Wansolmoana — 'one salt ocean' — Australia's new repository of Pacific culture and history

image.altText: A woman in a hat stands in a paddock holding a bunch of purple and blue flowers.

items.synopsis: Tamworth mum Shona Robilliard started with a few seeds in her veggie patch, but in search of a better work-life balance she's ditched the vegetables and is now a fully fledged cut-flower farmer.

title.children: Among the grain crops of northern NSW, there's a boom of farming mums planting fields of flowers

image.altText: A woman in a blue and red Aussie Rules guernsey and shorts walks towards camera and smiles.

items.synopsis: Women who were previously sidelined from Aussie Rules are now embracing their opportunity to play the sport they love, as part of the AFL Victoria Masters league.

title.children: AFL Victoria Masters a chance for older women to live out their pipedreams

image.altText: A young Aboriginal woman holds up a photo of a young child and painted handprints on paper

items.synopsis: Amelia Huddleston took her feverish and coughing son to the local health clinic three times in the week he died. She believes her son could have survived if he'd had the right care.

title.children: 'He could have survived': Grieving mother pleads for governments to fix remote health clinics

image.altText: a woman in a wheelchair on the driveway of a home

items.synopsis: An NDIS policy designed to protect vulnerable Australians from being overcharged has had the unintended consequence of forcing people who live alone out of their homes in the middle of a housing crisis.

title.children: Amy to be forced out of NDIS-funded home during housing crisis because she doesn't want to share

image.altText: A generic photo of a shiny stone kitchen bench in a modern home.

items.synopsis: A new report has called for a ban on all engineered stone in Australia, but governments will not make any changes until they decide on a "national response".

title.children: Popular kitchen bench material could be banned after report finds it has led to spike in silicosis

image.altText: A woman with brown hair wearing a sparkly top smiles at camera

items.synopsis: Australian media personality Abbie Chatfield announces she will not be co-hosting the Fridayz Live 2023 Australia and New Zealand concert tour next month, citing sexual harassment allegations against the tour's headline act, US pop star Jason Derulo.

title.children: 'I don't feel comfortable': Abbie Chatfield quits hosting gig over allegations against headline act

image.altText: Sydney Sixers cricketer Alyssa Healy stands in front of a microphone during an interview.

items.synopsis: The WBBL season is over for Alyssa Healy after she was bitten by her dog, with the Australia star battling to be fit for the end-of-year tour of India.

title.children: Alyssa Healy to miss entire WBBL season as she recovers from dog bite

image.altText: Jeep car held by a crane with doors taken off, writing all over it and people standing by watching it be destroyed.

items.synopsis: A Queensland man who made international headlines after pulling apart then setting fire to his faulty Jeep welcomes the importer's new commitment to better handle customer complaints.

title.children: Man who famously destroyed his $49K Jeep finds new ACCC probe 'surprising'
